body:
FWIW there is one example in the User Guide. It doesn't reference `StoreScope` but demonstrates how to inject a resource from a `LauncherSessionListener` via the session-scoped store:
https://docs.junit.org/current/user-guide/#launcher-api-launcher-session-listeners-tool-example-usage

That being said, I see your point about the documentation having quite a bit room for improvement.

> Incorrect usage of `GLOBAL` namespace thinking it provides JVM-wide scope

How are you executing your tests to need JVM-wide scope? While the new session-level scope is intended for such use cases, I would like to learn more about your use cases.

* Are you using multiple test engines that need to share resources?
* Are you (or the build tool you're using?) calling `Launcher.execute` multiple times within the same JVM?

I may have used improper terminology here. Forgive my ignorance. I'll try to best describe my use case.

> How are you executing your tests to need JVM-wide scope? While the new session-level scope is intended for such use cases, I would like to learn more about your use cases.

We have a collection of test extensions which maintain expensive resources (containers, db instances, mock servers, etc). We have written our test extensions to store a reference to those resources as a lazy static private field in our extensions. This way our resources could be used across "test containers". We did it that way because beforeAll is not always before all tests we selected to run, it was merely before all tests in a given group of tests. When I say jvm scope, I am trying to express that there are resources I would like to initialize once before all test containers, share across all test containers, and then close after all tests are done.  

During the upgrade to 5.13, we found that our connections to those static resources were being closed because we were storing those connections in the extension context for injection into our tests. My first attempt to fix it was to disable auto close with a property, but changing default behavior is probably not sustainable. I then learned that I could store things in the root context (or the GLOBAL namespace?), but I worried about key collisions. It was only after that that I ran into the 5.13 release note about the StoreScope, which seems to fit my needs quite well, and our connections aren't closed between test containers.

> It doesn't reference StoreScope but demonstrates how to inject a resource from a LauncherSessionListener via the session-scoped store:
https://docs.junit.org/current/user-guide/#launcher-api-launcher-session-listeners-tool-example-usage

Perhaps a LauncherSessionListener would be a better part of the lifecycle to hook into, but I am not familiar with the junit-platofrm-launcher api, and I don't remember this existing last time I did a deep dive on our test extensions. (perhaps 5.9.x era). I will read into this separate from this request from documentation.

> Are you (or the build tool you're using?) calling Launcher.execute multiple times within the same JVM?

We use Failsafe with a `forkCount` of `1`  for integration tests in this case, so I don't think `Launcher.execute` is called multiple times. This is not something I normally consider.

> I then learned that I could store things in the root context (or the GLOBAL namespace?), but I worried about key collisions. If there's a single call to `Launcher.execute`, storing resources in the `Store` of the root `ExtensionContext` with a custom namespace will work as you'd expect. > It was only after that that I ran into the 5.13 release note about the StoreScope, which seems to fit my needs quite well, and our connections aren't closed between test containers. If there are multiple calls to `Launcher.execute` (or you can't be sure), you should use `StoreScope.LAUNCHER_SESSION`. For every namespace, you can think of it as there being a hierarchy like this: > > It doesn't reference StoreScope but demonstrates how to inject a resource from a LauncherSessionListener via the session-scoped store: > > [docs.junit.org/current/user-guide#launcher-api-launcher-session-listeners-tool-example-usage](https://docs.junit.org/current/user-guide/#launcher-api-launcher-session-listeners-tool-example-usage) > > Perhaps a LauncherSessionListener would be a better part of the lifecycle to hook into, but I am not familiar with the junit-platofrm-launcher api, and I don't remember this existing last time I did a deep dive on our test extensions. (perhaps 5.9.x era). I will read into this separate from this request from documentation. That's ok. You can keep creating resources ("lazily") in your extensions and cache them in the store. > > Are you (or the build tool you're using?) calling Launcher.execute multiple times within the same JVM? > > We use Failsafe with a `forkCount` of `1` for integration tests in this case, so I don't think `Launcher.execute` is called multiple times. This is not something I normally consider. IIRC with `forkCount = 1`, Failsafe will call `Launcher.execute` only a single time. However, to be on the safe side, I'd recommend using a store with `StoreScope.LAUNCHER_SESSION`.

Thank you. That image is incredibly helpful. I suppose the auto close calls occur at the end of each of the scopes described in the image. Consider this request just a simple request for improved documentation in the userguide and/or the javadocs on those scope enums, namespace, and store apis.

> I suppose the auto close calls occur at the end of each of the scopes described in the image. 

That's correct. üëç
